post_text: Here's Colonial Elementary School 4th Grader Alex Esposito with the mask he painted "tie-die style" with the watercolors he received in the summer art pack at Conshohocken Elementary! He also used the colored pencils and drawing paper to illustrate his summer reading project. Alex read “Who was Alexander the Great.” because they share the same name.

Congratulations to Plymouth Whitemarsh High School seniors Alexander Szperka and Dean Suchsland who have been named Semifinalists in the 2021 National Merit® Scholarship Program. As Semifinalists, Szperka and Suchsland have an opportunity to continue in the competition for some 7,600 National Merit Scholarships worth more than $30 million that will be offered next spring.
#pwproud
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~news-id/7878

post_text: In honor of 9/11, Whitemarsh Elementary School annually celebrates heroes and gathers by the flagpole to sing patriotic songs and recognize local first responders. In this excerpt from this year's virtual ceremony, WE Music Teacher Kristy Langis asks first graders what a hero is, second graders what makes America great, and third graders why they're proud to be American.

We just found out about this great Wednesday evening online series sponsored by Remake Learning that features national experts to help parents and caregivers navigate "a school year like no other."

Tonight's sessions: "Supporting young children's social and emotional wellness as we return to school" at 7 p.m. and "Tweens, teens and mental health" at 8 p.m. Sessions are free on Zoom, Wednesdays through the end of September.

For more information and to register, click on the link: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/back-to-school-series-for-parents-caregivers-20200908

post_text:
Welcome to Gerald James, Colonial's new Equity, Diversity and Instruction Officer! Mr. James will expand on the District's ongoing efforts to build a culture of diversity and inclusion.

"I am committed to this cause and am looking forward to working collaboratively with students, staff and parents; not only to the benefit of our students, this District, and the community, but to society at large," said Mr. James.

#TeamColonial

https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/colonial-appoints-new-equity-diversity-and-instruction-officer-20200902

The free meals are again available for all school-age children in the Colonial School District. However, families will need to use the new order form to select how many students and your pick-up location (Plymouth Whitemarsh High School, Conshohocken Elementary, or the Colonial Neighborhood Council). Meal packs include five breakfasts and five lunches.

Order window is Wednesday through Friday at noon for the next week's pick up, so order your meal packets today!

https://www.colonialsd.org/departments/food-services/2020-meal-order-info

post_text:
Back in June, Sami Zivitz, a freshman at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy and Colonial community member, collected donations to create summer art kits for all of the students at Conshohocken Elementary School. The kits included paint, paper, modeling foam, colored pencils and more — and went home with the children at the end of the school year.

“I always had a creative side, especially when I was these kids’ age,” said Sami. “I thought they would enjoy it.”

Let’s see what you created, Conshy families! Help us show off your summer artwork! Send us your pictures here: https://www.colonialsd.org/send-us-your-photo
text:
Back in June, Sami Zivitz, a freshman at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy and Colonial community member, collected donations to create summer art kits for all of the students at Conshohocken Elementary School. The kits included paint, paper, modeling foam, colored pencils and more — and went home with the children at the end of the school year.

“I always had a creative side, especially when I was these kids’ age,” said Sami. “I thought they would enjoy it.”

Let’s see what you created, Conshy families! Help us show off your summer artwork! Send us your pictures here: https://www.colonialsd.org/send-us-your-photo

post_text:
Order today through Friday at noon and pick up your meals from Colonial Food Services next Tuesday at PWHS or Conshohocken Elementary! Free meals are only for those who qualify. Meal packs include five breakfasts and five lunches and are also available for $3.50 for those who qualify for reduced meals and $20.50 for students who pay full price.

If you can't make the Tuesday 11:30 a.m.-1 p.m. window, you can also sign up to pick up your meals on Wednesday, 5 a.m.-2 p.m., at the Colonial Neighborhood Council, 107 E. 4th Avenue, Conshohocken.

For directions and links, visit: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/new-meal-pick-up-procedures-20200818

PWHS Seniors: Deadline is end of business day today, Friday, August 21, to order your Senior Sunrise shirt for the first day of school! They'll be ordering shirts for the whole Class of 2021, so all seniors should complete the form. If your family is experiencing financial hardship at this time, the cost will be covered.

post_text:
The Colonial School District is receiving approximately $900,000 in grant funding from the state and county through the federal Coronavirus Aid, Relief and Economic Security (CARES) Act.

"We're investing these funds to improve access for all students as we deliver our curriculum remotely and to prepare for their eventual safe return to Colonial classrooms," said Dr. Mike Christian, Superintendent of Schools. "These grants ensure that the bulk of that cost will not take away from resources our children need for learning."

https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/district-receives-covid-related-grant-funding-from-county-and-state-20200817

post_text: The campus that includes Plymouth Whitemarsh High School, Colonial Elementary School, and the athletic fields is being repaved. If you are on campus, please follow all signs closely to determine where you can drive or park. Do not move cones or other barriers. Please enter from Germantown Pike. The Flourtown Road entrance will be closed at various times during the project. The project should be complete by end of day on Thursday, August 27.

post_text:
Due to the unknowns surrounding events for the upcoming school year, the Colonial School District will not be distributing a printed calendar. However, you can stay up-to-date through notifications or by exporting your child's school calendar from the District website to your phone or other device.

Go to the link below for a page of current calendars. Click on the blue "filter" icon to select a calendar or calendars to view on that page. Click on the gray icon to select a calendar for exporting to your phone or other device. Click on the orange icon to receive email or text alerts for a particular calendar.

https://www.colonialsd.org/calendar

post_text:
Tomorrow (Thursday, August 13) is the last day for picking up free summer meals. Thanks to all of the food services staff for their hard work this summer!

Due to new USDA Guidelines, when meal distribution starts up again the week of August 31, free meals will only be available for students who qualify. Students who qualify for reduced meals will be able to purchase meals for 30¢ per breakfast and 40¢ per lunch, and all other students can purchase meals at the regular price.

Click on the link to apply for free or reduced lunch:
https://www.colonialsd.org/departments/food-services/free-reduced-meals

post_text:
Congratulations to PWHS and CMTHS - Central Montco Technical High School student William Harris for winning a substantial auto service tools award, given by Eileen and Ben Lawler (BHL Residential Preservation) in memory of their good friend John Jackalous Jr. "Jacko"!
#PWProud
shared_text:
CMTHS - Central Montco Technical High School
July 28 at 8:05 PM ·

A substantial auto service tools award was given by Eileen and Ben Lawler (BHL Residential Preservation) in memory of their good friend John Jackalous Jr. "Jacko" was a graduate of Automotive Training Center, an ASE Certified Master Technician and an amazing person.
The CMTHS recipients are well deserving, skilled students who are taking the steps to become successful in their automotive careers.
One of the award recipients is CMTHS Auto Service and PWHS student, William Harris (pictured). Congratulations! @colonialsdpa

post_text:
Congratulations to Plymouth Elementary Principal Rosemarie Gregitis, who's been promoted to Colonial's Director of Curriculum, Instruction and Assessment!

"Mrs. Gregitis' experience in the areas of supervision, program evaluation, professional development and curriculum writing will be invaluable to us in the District Office," said Colonial Superintendent of Schools Dr. Mike Christian.

Mrs. Gregitis will remain in the dual role of PE principal to open the new school year.

#teamcolonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/gregitis-elevated-to-top-curriculum-post-20200713

post_text:
Thanks to everyone for participating! With 75% of our families responding to the Back-to-School survey and 500+ volunteers taking part in 25+ focus group meetings over the past couple weeks, we have a lot of great data and ideas to help us put together plans for the opening of school in the fall. Tune into this month's school board meeting at 7 p.m. on July 23 to see how all the parts fit together!
#wearecolonial
#colonialstrong

The Plymouth Whitemarsh High School Microfinance Club has traditionally provided small loans to people in the developing world — empowering the recipients to start their own businesses, finance their educations and improve their standard of living.

However, recently, the PWHS Microfinance Club made a donation closer to home, with a $500 gift to the Colonial Neighborhood Council.

#MakingADifferenceinCSD
#PWProud

https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-microfinance-club-supports-colonial-neighborhood-council-20200620

shared_text:
Colonial School District Education Foundation
June 11 at 6:53 PM ·

Tonight CSDEF Co-Presidents Jori Broad and Annette Swartz, along with David Krieger and David Roomberg (2 of the donors) held a mini awards night for the newest scholarship awarded through the CSDEF, called The Boys of '92. Each year, $2000 will be awarded to a graduating PWHS senior, donated by the Boys of '92.

From David Krieger, PW graduate and donor, "11 of us graduated from Plymouth Whitemarsh HS in 1992 and we have remained super close ever since. Today we presented the first recipient of the “Boys of ‘92” Scholarship Fund. We hope to continue recognizing one deserving graduate for years to come. It’s great to give back to the community that has given us all so much."

Thank you Boys of '92 and congratulations Ben Felgoise, the inaugural recipient of this award!

Congratulations, Ben! Ben Felgoise is the first winner of the Boys of '92 Scholarship.

Colonial School District Education Foundation
June 11 at 6:53 PM ·

Tonight CSDEF Co-Presidents Jori Broad and Annette Swartz, along with David Krieger and David Roomberg (2 of the donors) held a mini awards night for the newest scholarship awarded through the CSDEF, called The Boys of '92. Each year, $2000 will be awarded to a graduating PWHS senior, donated by the Boys of '92.

From David Krieger, PW graduate and donor, "11 of us graduated from Plymouth Whitemarsh HS in 1992 and we have remained super close ever since. Today we presented the first recipient of the “Boys of ‘92” Scholarship Fund. We hope to continue recognizing one deserving graduate for years to come. It’s great to give back to the community that has given us all so much."

Thank you Boys of '92 and congratulations Ben Felgoise, the inaugural recipient of this award!

shared_text:
Colonial School District Education Foundation
June 15 at 5:54 PM ·

This year, CSDEF donated funds for a new PWHS Senior Award. The PW Scholarship committee identified Seniors who represent the vision and mission of the Foundation.

CSDEF Vision:
A unified and future-ready community that supports high-quality education and takes pride in the Colonial School District

CSDEF Mission:

The CSDEF will build community connections and generate resources for expanding and enriching programs that promote excellence in the Colonial School District.

Congratulations to PW Senior, Marcaela Allen, our inaugural recipient of this award!

We can't wait to see what great things you will do.

Congratulations to Conshohocken Elementary Third Grader Aiden Smith and Second Grader Willie Villanueva, winners in the Conshohocken Police Department annual bike giveaway.

“What I love about the bike presentation is it enables us to have a positive encounter and to recognize remarkable young citizens," said Chief George Metz.

The winners are selected based on how they model the characteristics of Respect, Responsibility, Trustworthiness, Caring, Fairness and Citizenship from the school's constitution.
#CEProud

https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/conshohocken-police-sponsor-annual-bike-giveaway-at-ce-20200612

Starting Monday, Colonial Elementary is the new location for the free meals program! Mrs. Crocco (below) and the rest of the food service staff will be providing meals through at least July 1.

Also, families are encouraged to apply now for free/reduced price school meals for the 2020-2021 school year. Those that qualify may receive further economic relief in the form of a Pandemic-EBT (P-EBT), a benefit introduced through the Family's First Coronavirus Response Act.

post_text:
On Sunday, Conshohocken Elementary Second Grade Teacher Courtland Jackson and a team of PWHS alumni led more than 100 cyclists in the Black Out X Ride Out bike ride from Conshohocken to the Philadelphia Art Museum and back to encourage unity.

"The event started when my friends and I decided to open up our weekly bike ride with the purpose of the uniting one another and educating how African Americans and People of Color live their daily lives in America," said Mr. Jackson.

#BlackOutXRideOut
#LoveOnYourNeighbor

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/conshohocken-elementary-teacher-helped-lead-black-out-x-ride-out-bike-ride-for-unity-20200609

post_text:
In PWHS English classes, seniors complete a "20% project" — a self-guided effort that involves exploring a passion, researching a topic or solving a problem. Class of 2020's Kelli Coles dedicated her 20% project to solving the problem of hunger.

"The children lit up as they saw some of their favorite snacks and foods being brought to them, and it brought me joy to know that at least one child did not go to sleep hungry that night," said Kelli.

Her April food drive brought in donations for 20 Philadelphia families, stranded students at Cheyney University of Pennsylvania, a Philadelphia soup kitchen and the Colonial Neighborhood Council.

#pwproud
#pw2020
#lookforthehelpers
#makingadifferenceinCSD

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-senior-dedicates-20-project-to-feeding-the-hungry-20200522

post_text:
Congratulations to Plymouth Whitemarsh High School senior Caleb Kelly who will swim for the NCAA Division I LaSalle University Explorers next year. A record-setter for the Colonials, Kelly went undefeated in dual meets and was named an All-American in the 50 freestyle and 100 freestyle this past season.
#PWProud
#GoColonials
#PW2020
Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/kelly-earns-full-scholarship-to-la-salle-20200517

Take a look at these drawings by CMS seventh graders for Advanced Math! The Wheel of Theodorus demonstrates that non-square integers are irrational numbers. Students created the spiral figure by drawing continuous right triangles and then used the Pythagorean Theorem to calculate each hypotenuse.

Due to Monday being Memorial Day, families will need to pick up Monday's grab-and-go meals this Friday, 11:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m.! All school-age children in Colonial can take advantage of free breakfasts and lunches. The normal schedule will resume on Wednesday, May 27 and will remain in place moving forward.
#colonialcommunity

Thank you to John Kennedy Subaru and Subaru of America, Inc. for supporting our summer meals program through the Colonial School District Education Foundation!
#ColonialCommunity
shared_text:
ABCNEWS.GO.COM
Video: Subaru provides 50 million meals to food banks across the country

Colonial School District Education Foundation
May 14 at 10:15 AM ·

Did you see the wonderful story on Good Morning America about Subaru of America, Inc. and how they saw a need and found a way to help in a big way! Subaru is a Presenting Sponsor of CSDEF and the Colonial SD summer meal program. Great work Subaru. Here is Subaru CEO Tom Doll on GMA.

post_text:
Here's more #pandemicpoetry from Colonial poets. This one is from a lesson onomatopoeia by Alan Shakirzyanov, first grader at Conshohocken Elementary:

Sounds of quarantine

Shriek, shriek that’s my pencil sharpener.
Sizzle, sizzle my mom’s making breakfast.
One, two, three, my dad’s doing pushups.
Snooze, snooze I’m taking a nap.
And the next morning it repeats again.
But a little different.
This time it went grr, grr.
And the breakfast was chop, chop.
And there were no pushups with dad.
And I did not snooze when I was sleeping.
And it goes again just like yesterday.
And then back to normal.

#colonialathome
text:
Here's more #pandemicpoetry from Colonial poets. This one is from a lesson onomatopoeia by Alan Shakirzyanov, first grader at Conshohocken Elementary:

Sounds of quarantine

Shriek, shriek that’s my pencil sharpener.
Sizzle, sizzle my mom’s making breakfast.
One, two, three, my dad’s doing pushups.
Snooze, snooze I’m taking a nap.
And the next morning it repeats again.
But a little different.
This time it went grr, grr.
And the breakfast was chop, chop.
And there were no pushups with dad.
And I did not snooze when I was sleeping.
And it goes again just like yesterday.
And then back to normal.

#colonialathome

post_text:
Colonial School District schools will replace traditional polling locations for the upcoming June 2 Primary Election. Voting will take place in the gymnasiums of each school, except the high school. The high school polling location will be in the large group instruction room at the front of the building adjacent to Colonial Drive. All polls are open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on June 2.

Click on this link to find out which school will be your precinct's voting location: https://www.colonialsd.org/uploaded/School_Board/2020_Primary_Polling_Locations.pdf

Registered voters who have not previously done so may skip the polling locations by applying for a mail-in ballot. Click on the link to go to the Montgomery County website for a link to an absentee ballot application: https://www.pavoterservices.pa.gov/OnlineAbsenteeApplication/#/OnlineAbsenteeBegin.

post_text:
Colonial Middle School seventh grader Julian Lucks has been putting his skills to work to help essential personnel during the quarantine. Since being home, Julian has made dozens of face shields using a 3D printer.

“My favorite part is using technology to help the people that help us every day,” said Julian.

The face shields have gone to local hospitals, emergency rooms, nursing homes, anesthesiologists, dental offices and more.

#makingadifferenceincsd
#lookforthehelpers
#colonialathome

post_text:
Check out this 2-in-1 "reverse" poem by CMS sixth grader Christopher Schaps (shown below). Read it traditionally from top to bottom for one message and then start with the last line and read it from bottom to top for a different story!

April was the saddest month ever
And don't try to convince me that
I should be happy in quarantine
Because when you take a closer look
The world is pretty sad and lonely right now
Even if
Some happiness does shine through once in a while
That happiness does not last long
And it's not true that
We have a choice over our emotions
Because
True happiness during quarantine can only be found
If you work at it
It's not true that happiness exists for everyone right now
I'm sure that you can agree that
The reality of quarantine
Creates
Sadness
It's something I can't change
And you'll never ever hear me say that
Quarantine has been fun

#colonialathome
Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/cms-sixth-graders-find-new-ways-to-express-themselves-during-quarantine-20200508

In K-3 technology classes across the Colonial School District, students are drawing or making circuits at home to help them learn how electricity works.

"Learning about circuits is important," said Conshohocken Elementary School (CE) third grader Cian Yakeley. "You may want to go to college and become someone who works in technology, and this helps with that. Also, it can help with fixing things around the house."
#colonialathome

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/conshohocken-elementary-students-make-circuits-at-home-20200508

AP U.S History students recently enjoyed a guest lecture from composer/lyricist Lin-Manuel Miranda. The creator of the musical, Hamilton, shared insights about the Founding Fathers, research methods and storytelling tips.

"I think it's terrific. This lecture had a lot of people excited — me at the top of the list," said PWHS AP U.S. History Teacher Bob Culp.

Read more about it:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/ap-us-history-students-20200502

post_text:
New date and time for working papers! Working papers will be distributed on Thursday morning, April 30, from 9:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m. in the Plymouth Whitemarsh High School main office vestibule. Please park in the front parking lot, not in the circle, and come to the front of the building. Colonial students do not need to bring proof of age, since we already have that in our records.

We will have security assisting with this process so everyone follows social distancing guidelines. Please do not socialize, and, as soon as you receive the papers, please leave the campus. Additionally, we ask that you wear a mask throughout the entire process.
text:
New date and time for working papers! Working papers will be distributed on Thursday morning, April 30, from 9:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m. in the Plymouth Whitemarsh High School main office vestibule. Please park in the front parking lot, not in the circle, and come to the front of the building. Colonial students do not need to bring proof of age, since we already have that in our records.

We will have security assisting with this process so everyone follows social distancing guidelines. Please do not socialize, and, as soon as you receive the papers, please leave the campus. Additionally, we ask that you wear a mask throughout the entire process.

Are you looking for a career in education? Colonial School District will be participating in the Montgomery County Recruitment Outreach Virtual Education Career Fair on Thursday, May 7, from 12 noon to 5 p.m.

Speak one-on-one with representatives from Montgomery County school districts. Pre-register by May 4 on the MCIU website: www.mciu.org/mcro. Candidates will be scheduled a designated time to speak one-on-one with representatives via Zoom.

#TeamColonial

post_text:
Colonial Board Meetings are going online starting with Monday's committee meeting triple header of Human Relations/Finance/Facilities Management and Transportation starting at 5:30 p.m.

Members of the public wishing to join any or all meetings may do so via the internet or by phone. To join any of these meetings by phone, please email csdsupport@colonialsd.org to receive the meeting ID and Password, then dial 1-929-436-2866 at the designated meeting time.

Each meeting will also be streamed live on the District’s YouTube channel. The url for each meeting will be posted in the BoardDocs section of the District website at https://go.boarddocs.com/pa/colonial/Board.nsf/Public.

Anyone wishing to sign up for public comment is asked to email csdsupport@colonialsd.org prior to start of the meeting. Questions that arise during the meeting should also be emailed to csdsupport@colonialsd.org. Please include your name, address, phone number, any affiliation and question in the email.

https://www.facebook.com/events/1820522498084939/

post_text:
The governor has announced that all Pennsylvania schools will remain closed through the academic year, However, remote learning will continue in Colonial starting Monday, April 13.

The District has three main goals during this time:

• Maintaining connections with students and families
• Providing solid instruction so that students can demonstrate growth
• Mitigating family stress

Read more about it in this letter from Superintendent Mike Christian: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/covid-19-update-04092020-20200409

#WeAreColonial
#ColonialatHome

post_text:
Remember there will be no free meal distribution this Friday, April 10. Pick up two days of breakfast and lunch on Monday and three days of meals on Wednesday at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School.

The program is available to all school-age children under 18 and students with special needs over 18 in the District. You don't have to be part of the free meals program to participate.

Families with the last names beginning with the letters A-L should arrive between 11:30 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. Families with the last names beginning with the letters M-Z should arrive between 12:00 p.m. and 12:30 p.m. Regular Monday, Wednesday, Friday meal pick up resumes on April 13.
#strangestspringbreakever
#wearecolonial

Thank you to the Colonial Neighborhood Council, restaurants and volunteers who helped with the meals program this week! Because of the wider restrictions on businesses and social gatherings, however, Colonial has had to switch to providing lunch and breakfast for any school age children under 18 as a “grab and go/drive through” at Ridge Park Elementary.

NOTE: THIS IS OPEN TO ALL SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN UNDER 18 (and Colonial students over 18 with special needs). YOU DON'T HAVE TO QUALIFY FOR FREE OR REDUCED LUNCH TO PARTICIPATE.

Pick up two days of meals per child on Monday, Wednesday and Friday, starting next week. Click on the link for details: https://www.colonialsd.org/our-schools/ridge-park-elementary/rp-news-item/~post/free-meals-program-announces-changes-20200320

post_text:
K-3 Parents/Guardians: The information on the hub contains a mix of online resources and printable worksheets.

• You do not need to print -- or complete -- every worksheet.
• Talk to your child to see what they need to practice most.
• Consider using a small whiteboard, chalkboard or plain paper to save on printing or if you don't have a printer.

Remember these assignments are for practice, not for a grade. Allow your child to make choices. Understanding what they need to practice is part of their growth.

If the closure goes past two weeks, the students will be getting specific assignments from their teachers, and our goal is to minimize the need for printing in the future.

post_text:
Note on Academics: The teacher in-service day on Monday, 3/16, was to be dedicated for instructional planning for an extended closure. Fortunately, our faculty and curriculum department had begun planning instructional activities prior to yesterday's announcement. Early next week, we will be posting information on the District's website with specific grade level activities for our elementary students. Our middle school and high school will be communicating initial academic activities for students, as well while planning additional assignments during the week. Many of our teachers will be utilizing Learning Management Systems such as Canvas and Google Classroom.

While we are faced with some challenging days ahead, Colonial is a community with a dedicated faculty and staff and filled with wonderful students. Please take this weekend to support one another and focus on your family.

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/covid-19-update-03132020-20200313

#WeAreColonial

post_text:
IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT

All schools in the Colonial School District will be closed for two weeks, starting Friday, March 13, due to the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and under the direction of Pennsylvania Governor Tom Wolf.

Elementary before and/or after school programs held in Colonial schools will continue operation through 6 p.m. today, Thursday, March 12. Saturday's SAT scheduled at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School is cancelled.

post_text:
ALL ORiGINALLY SCHEDULED PERFORMANCES OF FROZEN JR. HAVE BEEN POSTPONED.

County officials and the Office of Public Health have advised school districts and municipalities that “it is time to seriously consider cancelling or postponing large gatherings of people within the county.”

Therefore, Colonial School District will be implementing restrictions/limitations until April 10, 2020.

It is our every intent to reschedule the five performances that were originally scheduled. We appreciate your patience in requesting refunds for tickets purchased; however we will be happy to refund your purchases immediately if that is your desire. Please contact CMS at 610 275-5100, ext. 7153, if you desire an immediate refund. Please note that future developments will dictate rescheduled dates or permanent cancellations and refunds will be made available at those times as well. Please note that when refunds are made, those tickets will be placed back in circulation for purchase.

Congratulations to the two Colonial Middle School Odyssey of the Mind teams for bringing back awards from the Southeastern Pennsylvania Regional Competition held recently at Pennridge High School.

The team of Lukas Nosal, Jackson De Guzman, Natalie Dyck, Ellen Fang, Miles Hormell, Thomas Warshaw, and Isaac Nolt took third in the Net Work problem and qualifies for the state competition. The team of Peyton Stauffer, Natalie Lieberman, Ethan Chapin, Ryan Bass, Sachita Upadhya and Aine McAleese brought home an OMER’s Award for displaying exceptional sportsmanship in coming to the aid of a competing team.

#CMSProud
#WeAreColonial

Attention homeowners and renters over 65, widowed age 50+, or permanently disabled age 18+: Colonial is offering a new Property Tax/Rent Rebate Program that piggybacks onto the state Property Tax/Rent Rebate Program. The income limit is $35,000 per year for homeowners and $15,000 for renters, and half of Social Security income is excluded.

Click on the link for information: https://www.colonialsd.org/community/tax-rebates

Encourage literacy worldwide during Read Across America Week! Plymouth Whitemarsh High School's Interact and UNICEF clubs are collecting pre-teen and teen books for Project Buku Buku. Simply drop new and gently used teen and pre-teen books off at the main office at PWHS.

Project Buku Buku is an English literacy program that makes education more accessible to girls living in rural settings in Indonesia.

#MakingADifferenceinCSD

post_text:
When Activist Nell Stokes was a 16-year-old high school student, she took part in the historic Montgomery, Alabama bus boycott in 1956. Later she fought against the organized effort to deny African Americans the right to vote. Earlier this week, she shared her story with the students at Colonial Middle School.

“I can learn a lot of things from her,” said seventh grader Aniya Wood. “She went through a lot.”

Ms. Stokes’ message for the students was one of looking past personal strife and having a sunny outlook.

“To have a positive attitude and think of themselves as the most important person in their lives,” she said. “Be encouraged by the things they can accomplish and do for themselves. Know that everyone is different, and yet we are all the same and we want and need the same things.”

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~news-id/7471
text:

Later she fought against the organized effort to deny African Americans the right to vote. Earlier this week, she shared her story with the students at Colonial Middle School.

“I can learn a lot of things from her,” said seventh grader Aniya Wood. “She went through a lot.”

Ms. Stokes’ message for the students was one of looking past personal strife and having a sunny outlook.

“To have a positive attitude and think of themselves as the most important person in their lives,” she said. “Be encouraged by the things they can accomplish and do for themselves. Know that everyone is different, and yet we are all the same and we want and need the same things.”

shared_text:

Flux hosted a group of creative 2nd and 3rd graders from Colonial School District. Students were presented with #STEM and #DesignThinking challenges to tackle as a group. Students engaged in hands-on tinkering activities as well as learned about the Design Thinking Process and rough prototyping. red c media was able to capture this day as well as some of the students' thoughts. post_text:
At Conshohocken Elementary School, first graders made rockets in honor of the first female African American astronaut, Mae Jemison.

"I'm inspired by her, because she never gave up," said CE first grader Joey Kilgallon. "Her teacher told her to be a nurse, but she wanted to be an astronaut. She followed her dream."

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/exploring-famous-african-americans-at-conshohocken-elementary-20200221

Parents/Guardians: Deadline is Sunday, February 16. Please take moment to have your voice heard by Colonial's Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Committee. The committee is comprised of parents/guardians, students, faculty and staff. They will be using the data to develop action plans to better serve our students and families. #WeAreColonial

Click on this link to take the survey: www.colonialsd.org/survey

If you'd like to get involved in the committee, please complete this form to receive an email notification of the next meeting: https://www.colonialsd.org/diversity-equity-and-inclusion-committee-sign-up-form

post_text:
Using movement, song, dance and spoken word, the Colonial Middle School Black Cultural Awareness Club and guests from the Plymouth Whitemarsh High School Black Cultural Awareness Club highlighted famous African Americans and shared the importance of being proud of who you are at Conshohocken Elementary School.

Seventh Grader Kayla Holmes was excited for the performance. "You get to tell people your culture, you get to do dances, and you get to teach little kids about Black Cultural Awareness and what we do at CMS," she said.

#CMSProud
#PWProud
#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/black-cultural-awareness-club-visited-conshohocken-elementary-20200204

post_text:
Colonial School District principals, curriculum supervisors and special education supervisors recently learned more about Visible Learning. Visible Learning looks at hundreds of factors (from untreated ADHD, working memory strength and family involvement to one-to-one technology, studying phonics and homework) and their effect on student achievement.

The project pulls in data from research that involves more than 80,000 studies and 300 million students.

#TeamColonial

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/colonial-leadership-team-studies-visible-learning-20200131

post_text:
The Colonial Board of School Directors approved a new senior citizen tax rebate program at their January meeting. The new District program will provide a 30% match of the refund received under the state program for property taxes or rent paid in 2019. The rebate will be paid to qualifying participants after July 1, 2020.

To be eligible for the Colonial rebate, qualified applicants would need to provide the School District with a copy of their Pennsylvania PA-1000 tax form with all of their income documentation, as well as their proof of payment of property taxes or rent. The participants would also provide proof that they received the Pennsylvania State Rebate by providing a copy of the check or proof of deposit in order to receive the 30% match.

Click on the link for more information about the Pennsylvania Property Tax/Rent Rebate Program: https://www.revenue.pa.gov/FormsandPublications/FormsforIndividuals/PTRR/Documents/2019_pa-1000_inst.pdf

#ColonialCommunity

Congratulations to the team of Plymouth Whitemarsh High School juniors Adrien Boyle and Noor Al-Hedeshi, sophomore Maya Hoffman and freshman Tori Pettine for winning the annual cardboard boat race.

"I was very surprised that our boat won," said Hoffman. "Our team is made up of students in Engineering 1, and we competed against all of the different Engineering classes. I was shocked we even made it across the water."

#PWProud
#STEAMinCSD

post_text:
Author Michael Patrick O'Neill Photography travels the world taking pictures of aquatic animals and their habitats and put together seven nonfiction books for children. This week, he visited the K-3 schools in Colonial, starting with Ridge Park on Monday.

"I liked when he was showing the really deep animals, like the diamond squid," said RP Third Grader Nathan Marsico. "They just looked cool, how they glowed in the dark."

Two students from each RP third grade class joined the author and Library Media Specialist Kathy Farrington for lunch.

#RPProud
#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/visiting-author-shared-reading-writing-and-science-with-k-3-students-20200114

Congratulations to Plymouth Whitemarsh High School senior Livia Truong who has announced she will play NCAA Division I field hockey next year at Hofstra University.

Third Grader Luke Olszyk arrived at Plymouth Elementary School via a police escort yesterday. Luke was the lucky recipient of the “Golden Ticket” placed in one of the Halloween safety bags distributed to the school’s students by the Plymouth Township Police Department last fall.

“It was really cool. I was so excited,” said Luke. “My favorite part was when I got to control the lights and the sirens. It made me feel like I was a police officer, and I felt really cool wearing the police hat and sunglasses into school.”

#PlymouthProud
#ColonialCommunity

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/student-gets-police-escort-to-school-20200108

post_text:
This year, the staff at Ridge Park Elementary took a break from their usual holiday pollyanna to collect toys for children at A.I. duPont Hospital for Children| Nemours. The toys were delivered by RP Kindergartener Jessica Jara and five-year-old Delaney Sturm, granddaughter of RP Second Grade Teacher Donna Sturm.

The best friends have been doing an annual toy drive since both visit the hospital several times each year for ongoing checkups.

"We're giving the toys to the kids at DuPont, so the kids can play with them when they're in the hospital," said Delaney Sturm, who'll be a kindergartener at Plymouth Elementary School in the fall. "It makes me feel good."

#WeAreColonial
#MakingADifferenceinCSD

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/making-a-difference-ridge-parks-nemoursalfred-i-dupont-hospital-for-children-toy-drive-20191223

post_text: What a great lesson!
shared_text:
PW Colonials Baseball is at Ambler Sports Academy.
December 30, 2019 at 1:49 PM · Ambler, PA ·

Our discussion to end our winter clinic today focused on how difficult the game of baseball is. We discussed the following:

Chris Paul makes 46.8% of his shots. He ranks 50th in NBA shooting percentage.

Josh Allen completed 58.8% of his passes this year. He ranked last among NFL quarterbacks.

Brett Maher made 66.7% of the field goals he attempted this season. He was last in the league and was cut by the Dallas Cowboys in week 14.

TIM ANDERSON WON THE AL BATTING TITLE IN 2019 AND LED ALL MAJOR LEAGUERS BY GETTING A HIT IN ONLY 33.5% OF HIS AT BATS.

Hitting a baseball isn't easy. Stay calm, use failure to help grow, and keep working in the off season! Thank you to our 6th, 7th, and 8th graders who came out today.
text:
What a great lesson!

PW Colonials Baseball is at Ambler Sports Academy.
December 30, 2019 at 1:49 PM · Ambler, PA ·

Our discussion to end our winter clinic today focused on how difficult the game of baseball is. We discussed the following:

Chris Paul makes 46.8% of his shots. He ranks 50th in NBA shooting percentage.

Josh Allen completed 58.8% of his passes this year. He ranked last among NFL quarterbacks.

Brett Maher made 66.7% of the field goals he attempted this season. He was last in the league and was cut by the Dallas Cowboys in week 14.

TIM ANDERSON WON THE AL BATTING TITLE IN 2019 AND LED ALL MAJOR LEAGUERS BY GETTING A HIT IN ONLY 33.5% OF HIS AT BATS.

Hitting a baseball isn't easy. Stay calm, use failure to help grow, and keep working in the off season! Thank you to our 6th, 7th, and 8th graders who came out today.

#MakingADifferenceinCSD

#PWProud

At seven years old, Ridge Park Elementary School student Carina Eades is already having an opportunity to realize one of her dreams.

“I used to watch The Nutcracker all the time when I was little, and then I got obsessed with it, and that’s when I started to dance,” said Carina.

This week the first grader will be performing with the Donetsk Ballet of Ukraine at Plymouth Whitemarsh High School as part of the International Ballet Exchange. During the performance, Carina will portray various roles, including an angel, a little doll and a Polichinelle.

#RPPRoud
#CSDSpotlight

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/student-spotlight-carina-eades-20191220

Plymouth Whitemarsh High School and Colonial Middle School each sent a team of emerging leaders to the Delaware Valley Coalition for Excellence & Equity Leadership Institute at The University of Pennsylvania.

"It really was motivating and helped you think about who you are internally," said CMS Student Amber Kinsey who particularly enjoyed a session on being a change agent. "Rather than just focusing on yourself, it emphasized how you can affect people as a whole."

Plymouth Whitemarsh High School's Interact and UNICEF clubs are collecting books for Project Buku Buku. Simply drop new and gently used teen and pre-teen books off at the main office at PWHS.

Project Buku Buku is an English literacy program that makes education more accessible to girls living in rural settings in Indonesia.

post_text:
Members of the CMS Gentleman's Club recently met with representatives of the Laurel House, one of the recipients of the club's recent drive to collect gloves for those in need.

"I was thinking it was getting colder outside and sometimes gloves could be expensive," said Aaron Walski who suggested the idea to collect gloves for the group's first community service project. "I thought we could help people get nice gloves for the winter."

The students collected over 930 pairs of gloves, 530 of which were donated to the Laurel House.

#WeAreColonial
#MakingADifferenceinCSD
#CMSProud

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/middle-school-students-provide-winter-warmth-20191210

post_text:
At Ridge Park Elementary School, Autism Support Teachers Tracey Quinn and Roni Berman are trying new ways to bring "Applied Behavior Analysis," or ABA, into the classroom.

"Children on the autism spectrum learn parts of a skill in isolation before they can connect them together to 'generalize' a skill," said Ms. Quinn. "My favorite part of my job is seeing the little steps they achieve each and every day leading up to their goals."

To help bring the latest ABA strategies and research to the classroom, Colonial has joined the Pennsylvania Training & Technical Assistance Network Autism Initiative — a statewide program that provides intensive training and classroom visits.

#RidgeParkProud
#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/new-initiative-for-rp-autism-support-classrooms-20191204

post_text:
While she was in town for Thanksgiving, PWHS Alum Phoebe Cornog stopped by her elementary alma mater to paint a mural in the Whitemarsh Elementary School cafeteria.

"You don't know what you're going to be when you're a second grader or a third grader, and I definitely wouldn't have imagined this. But I remember feeling really cool when I won the spaghetti dinner poster contest," said Ms. Cornog who owns her own business, Pandr Design Co, with a partner. "It's a real trip being back here and doing something for the school."

#PWProud
@pandrdesignco

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-alum-returns-to-paint-a-mural-at-whitemarsh-elementary-20191127

Volunteers Needed for Dec. 17 Senior Citizen event

The Colonial School District is seeking volunteers to assist with the annual Senior Citizen Winter Concert Lunch on Tuesday, December 17 in the Colonial Elementary School gymnasium. Volunteers are needed between 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. to assist food services staff in stocking the buffet lines and serving lunch to more than 350 guests. Volunteer clearances are not needed for this event. If interested, please email dsherman@colonialsd.org. Thank you!

Five newly elected members of the Colonial Board of School Directors — Chris Epstein, Susan Moore, Beth Patruno, Cathy Peduzzi and Beth Suchsland — were sworn into office at the Board’s annual reorganization meeting on December 2.

The Board elected Susan Moore to a one-year term as Board president and Beth Suchsland as vice president. The five newly elected members join seated members Jennifer Dow, Eunice Franklin-Becker, Rosemary Northcutt and Adam Schupack.

#TeamColonial
#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/colonial-school-board-reorganizes-20191203

post_text: All Colonial schools will open on time today, Monday, 12/2, We will continue to monitor the weather and may dismiss early if needed.
text: All Colonial schools will open on time today, Monday, 12/2, We will continue to monitor the weather and may dismiss early if needed.

post_text:
Colonial Families,

I hope you have had an enjoyable and relaxing Thanksgiving break.

Please know that we are communicating with local authorities, consulting our weather services and will be traveling roads early in the morning to monitor conditions. As is our practice, we will make a decision on the opening of schools by approximately 5:30 a.m. As always, all decisions are made with the safety of our students in mind.

All families will be called if there is a decision to delay or close schools. Please consult the emergency weather information page on our website for additional information. https://www.colonialsd.org/community/inclement-weather-communications

Dr. Michael Christian
Superintendent of Schools

post_text:
Colonial Middle School Teacher Ansley Dawidziuk was one of twelve people named a Best Buddies Champion for eastern Pennsylvania. The title honored their dedication to the Best Buddies Pennsylvania program and challenged the dozen to go out and raise money to fund new Best Buddies groups in Pennsylvania.

“We all did a great job,” said Ms. Dawidziuk. “Together, we raised $95,000 for Best Buddies, and it takes about $1,000 to start a new program. So if you think about it that way, that’s a lot of new programs.

#MakingADifferenceinCSD

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/making-a-difference-best-buddies-champion-20191127

post_text:
Newsweek named Plymouth Whitemarsh among the top 5,000 STEM high schools for 2020. PW's dedication to STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics) led to the development of the EDI (Entrepreneurship, Design and Innovation) department and lab at the high school, a nationally recognized engineering program and the College Board’s inaugural AP Computer Science Female Diversity Award.
#PWProud
#STEAMinCSD
Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-named-one-of-top-stem-high-schools-in-country-20191119

post_text:
On Election Day, select PWHS teachers worked on the new International Baccalaureate Career Programme that will kick off next year for students interested in Business or Design Technology.

“I think the exciting part about this program is the potential for students to engage in independent study on something that’s interesting for them and that they’re passionate about,” said Rebecca Hepler, an English as a Second Language teacher at PWHS who will be working with the IBCP students on a language development requirement.

Want to learn more about the IBCP? Come to the Curriculum Committee Meeting of the Colonial School Board tomorrow: Monday, November 18, 6 p.m. in the PWHS Library Media Center.

John's favorite thing about his new school are the "nice people." Welcome, John!

#WeAreColonial

post_text:
Colonial Elementary School marked their first anniversary as a #NoPlaceForHate School by continuing their commitment to respecting differences and being kind and incorporating lessons from the District-wide school climate program Rachel's Challenge.

"My favorite part about the assembly was when we had beach balls, and everybody wanted to be part of it," said CES Fifth Grader Blake Ambler, one of the schools No Place For Hate Ambassadors. "That made me think that everybody really wanted to show the rest of the school that they wanted to be kind."

#WeAreColonial
#MakingADifferenceinCSD

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/making-a-difference-no-place-for-hate-at-ces-20191107

post_text:
Plymouth Elementary celebrated National School Bus Safety Week with coffee and donuts — and handmade thank you cards — for the drivers last Friday.

"I enjoy being a bus driver, because we get to spend time and form a bond with the kids," said Kyle Butler. "You also get to see them grow through the years. I've seen my kindergarteners from last year, who are my first graders this year, teaching the new kindergarteners how to act and behave on the bus. It's interesting to watch them progress."

#TeamColonial

The school also works with the drivers for it's new Safe Rider Program.

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pe-recognizes-bus-drivers-during-national-school-bus-safety-week-and-beyond-20191030

Mr. Anthony Stover (second from right), Community Relations Director for the Philadelphia Ronald McDonald House spoke at the PWHS National Honor Society Induction Ceremony on Thursday. Here he is with the NHS officers and costumes they're donating to the Ronald McDonald House when volunteers from the NHS travel into the city to serve breakfast there.⁠
⁠
“Whenever I can spread our mission for creating a community of comfort for families with seriously ill children, I’m all for it. I love sharing what we do,” said Mr. Stover. “I’m also looking forward to them coming to the House. I always say there’s nothing cooler than kids helping kids.” ⁠
⁠
#PWProud⁠
#WeAreColonial

"Plymouth Rocks and Reads" brought together Plymouth Elementary families for an evening of spreading kindness — the message of the new Rachel's Challenge school climate initiative in Colonial. Participants painted kindness messages on rocks for a rock garden on the playground and then took part in an interactive read aloud with a book about kindness.

"My favorite thing was that I got to see my friend and see a book that was really fun," said PE student Phoebe Best.

#MakingADifferenceinCSD
#rachelschallenge
#startachainreaction
#kindness

Plymouth Whitemarsh High School inducted 150+ students into the National Honor Society on Thursday. The group highlights students representing the four pillars of NHS: scholarship, leadership, service and character.

"Being a part of NHS is so exciting, because it's a great organization that brings together the best of the best of PW," said PWHS Senior Tara Al-Saleem, coordinator of the NHS. "It also encourages kids to go out and do service opportunities in our community and in the greater Philadelphia area."

#PWProud
#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-inducts-150-students-into-2019-2020-national-honor-society-20191025

post_text:
Colonial Middle School student council members and Colonial School Board members were the first to break ground on the new middle school at a ceremony on October 21.

During the ceremony, Superintendent of Schools Dr. Michael Christian spoke of the foundation about to be laid for the new building and the foundation for the future that will be built within its walls.

"What matters is what happens inside this building and the foundation that we create with our children who will become the next leaders," Dr. Christian said. "That's what really makes communities like this so strong."

#WeAreColonial

Learn more about what to expect and a project timeline at a community meeting tonight: Tuesday, October 22, 6 p.m. at Colonial Middle School!

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/colonial-breaks-ground-for-new-middle-school-20191022

Congratulations to PWHS Junior Ava Borkowski for scoring her 100th career goal in the Colonials 8-2 win at North Penn on October 17. The landmark goal was the first of four in the game for Borkowski, who leads the Philadelphia region in goals scored this season with 51 and points with 108.

Borkowski's 103 career goals are believed to be the most ever scored by a PW field hockey player — and she has another year to go!

#PWProud

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/borkowski-scores-100th-career-goal-20191018

post_text:
For National School Lunch Week, the CMS cafeteria celebrated PA Preferred Day by offering regionally produced foods and ingredients. The menu included drumsticks from chickens raised in New Holland, items made with flour milled in Hatfield, locally grown produce, and milk from Lancaster. But nothing could beat how local the fresh basil was on the Margherita pizza — it was grown in the school's aquaponics system in the front light court.

"I just wanted to try something new. The chicken was good," said eighth grader Kharee Davis, who was also enjoying a fresh peach. "It's good to eat local, because it's more healthy."

https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/cms-cafeteria-celebrates-pa-preferred-day-20191018

#TeamColonial
#NSLW19
#allyoucaneatfruitsandveggies

post_text:
Colonial has adopted Rachel's Challenge — a K-12 initiative with the mission of "making schools safer, more connected places where bullying and violence are replaced with kindness and respect."

A program specifically created for parents/guardians and community members will be held Wednesday, October 23 and repeated on Thursday, October 24. Both presentations will be held at 7 p.m. at Colonial Elementary School. Learn more about Rachel Scott, a victim of the Columbine High School shooting in 1999, and how her writings encourage people to create a chain reaction of kindness and compassion.

The evening programs are not meant for students under grade seven. Representatives from Rachel's Challenge will make developmentally and age-appropriate presentations for all grade levels in Colonial schools during the week of October 21.

https://www.facebook.com/events/759551554517509/

CMS sixth graders spent nearly an hour in the library launching erasers, playing with blocks and marbles, and swinging around open containers of paint — in order to better understand Newton's Laws of Motion.

"It's helping us understand Newton's laws more, because it's showing examples we can relate to," said CMS Sixth Grader Rosie Ounsworth.

#WeAreColonial
#STEAMinCSD

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/cms-students-go-hands-on-with-newtons-laws-of-motion-20191008

Help Colonial kick-off construction of the new 232,000 square foot middle school at a groundbreaking on Oct. 21 at 5 p.m. and then learn all about what the project entails at a community meeting at CMS on Oct. 22 at 6 p.m.!

"I want to thank the School Board, administration and the CMS staff for their hard work and commitment during the design and development stage," said Superintendent of Schools Dr. Mike Christian. "We have been fortunate to have good partners in the leadership of Plymouth Township and the Central Montco Tech School, the residents in the neighborhood, KCBA Architects and D'Huy Engineering, Inc. This wouldn't be possible without their collaboration."

#WeAreColonial

PWHS students in the AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination) elective learn the tools that they need to be more successful in the classroom and prepare for college.

With many AVID students being the first in their families to continue their education after high school, they also enjoy campus visits as part of the program — including a recent visit to Temple University.

Read more about it in this recap by Senior Ryan Henry: https://www.colonialsd.org/our-schools/plymouth-whitemarsh-high/pwhs-news-item/~post/pwhs-avid-students-visit-temple-university-20191007

post_text:
Plymouth Elementary School staff welcomed the East Norriton Police Department and their pink police car to kick off #BreastCancerAwarenessMonth in the Colonial School District. The event was organized by PE First Grade Teacher Helene Pileggi, a breast cancer survivor, who wanted to honor the other cancer survivors at the school.

“It’s really about supporting each other, being positive and how everyone comes together to fight this battle,” said Mrs. Pileggi.

To her surprise, the East Norriton Police had dedicated the car to the teacher. The wrap has “#teamhelene” as part of the design, in addition to the famous image of Rosie the Riveter.
#MakingADifferenceinCSD
#TeamColonial
#TeamHelene
Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/making-a-difference-breast-cancer-awareness-month-20191002

Plymouth Whitemarsh High School Junior Ava Borkowski topped the ranks for Goal Leaders for the second week in a row according to Philafieldhockey.com, with an average of 2.89 goals per game or 26 goals in the nine games so far this season. The site also recognized Ava as one of the top attachers of the week.

"Ava has been a dominant force for our attack this season. She has phenomenal stick skills and great decision-making ability in the offensive circle," said PWHS Field Hockey Head Coach Charise Halteman. "Her efforts have helped our team maintain its undefeated record so far this season."

#PWProud
#GoColonials

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/our-schools/plymouth-whitemarsh-high/pwhs-news-item/~post/ava-borkowski-named-regional-top-field-hockey-goal-leader-20190926

post_text:
Colonial Board of School Directors unanimously approved an agreement of sale to purchase the Romano property on Belvoir Road for $6.85 million.

When the sale is finalized, the District plans to continue to use the property as a bus depot in a lease agreement with First Student. The First Student agreement includes built in rental increases, and the District expects the property to pay for itself in approximately 40 years. Keeping the transportation company in the District also saves Colonial on increased fuel and rental costs.

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/board-approves-agreement-of-sale-for-romano-property-20190926

post_text:
This past summer, the PW Latin Club made connections to what they learned — and with each other — during a ten-day visit to Italy, where they took in the sights and culture of Venice, Florence, Rome, Vatican City and Pompeii.

"I feel like the Italy trip meant so much to me because it was a culmination of my years in Latin," says Megan Flanagan, a current PWHS senior, and secretary of Latin Club. "Not just going to see the cities we learned so much about for five years, but really sharing the experience with all the people I took the class with. After finishing AP with my best friends, I couldn't have asked for a better way to say goodbye to Latin classes at PW."

Read about their travels in this article written by PWHS Senior Aryaa Moudgal: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-latin-club-shares-their-trip-to-italy-20190913

#PWTarquiniusSuperbus?
#CSDSummer
#WeAreColonial

Congratulations to Plymouth Whitemarsh High School senior Cade Missimer for being named a Semifinalist in the 2020 National Merit® Scholarship Program. Cade is among the top 1% of approximately 1.5 million juniors in about 21,000 high schools who took the qualifying exam — and one of two Semifinalists this year at PWHS.

Cade plans to major in education in college.

#PWProud
#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/eisner-and-missimer-are-national-merit-scholarship-semifinalists-20190916
text:
Congratulations to Plymouth Whitemarsh High School senior Cade Missimer for being named a Semifinalist in the 2020 National Merit® Scholarship Program. Cade is among the top 1% of approximately 1.5 million juniors in about 21,000 high schools who took the qualifying exam — and one of two Semifinalists this year at PWHS.

Cade plans to major in education in college.

#PWProud
#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/eisner-and-missimer-are-national-merit-scholarship-semifinalists-20190916

post_text:
Congratulations to PWHS junior Aja Smith for being named Pennsylvania's MaxPreps/American Volleyball Coaches Association (AVCA) Player of the Week for the week of September 16.

"Aja is a great choice for this honor," said PWHS Girls Volleyball Head Coach Seely Byler. "She is a junior team captain this year and has led our team in overall earned points this season."

The honor recognizes "the nation's best" with the top player in each state, based on the statistics that players earned the week before.

#PWProud
#GoColonials
Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/our-schools/plymouth-whitemarsh-high/pwhs-news-item/~post/pwhs-junior-aja-smith-named-pas-volleyball-player-of-the-week-20190919

post_text:
On September 17, 1787, Delegates to the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia signed the Constitution of the United States. On September 17, 2019, students at Conshohocken Elementary School honored the day by signing the Constitution of CE.

"Many years ago, in America, they signed a constitution today. This one's for our school," said CE third grader Vincent Makoid. "It's so people will be nice."

#WeAreColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/conshohocken-elementary-celebrates-constitution-day-20190917

post_text:
Monday is a Colonial Board of School Directors Committee Meeting triple header in the District Office General Meeting Room on the first floor of Colonial Elementary School.

- Find out how Colonial schools are doing with the 2019 Achievement Report at the Curriculum meeting at 5 p.m.

- Learn about Rachel's Challenge and the 2019-2020 District Communications Plan at the Community Relations and Student Life/Safety and Wellness Committee meeting at 6 p.m.

- Talk about: Policy #113.5 - Special Education Evaluations and Independent Evaluations at Public Expense, Policy # 801 - Public records, and Policy # 903 - Public Participation in Board Meetings at the Policy Committee meeting at 7 p.m.

post_text:
To recognize Patriot's Day, Whitemarsh Elementary School students sang patriotic songs and passed out thank you notes to first responders. Representatives from first, second and third grade also shared their thoughts about life in the United States. The third graders wrote about what made them proud to be Americans.

"I know I am free, and no one can tell me who I can or cannot play with," said WE third grader Lily Greis. "I feel safe at home and at Whitemarsh."

"I have equal rights and I am safe," said classmate Juliet Tizer. "America believes in treating people fairly."

#neverforget

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/honoring-heroes-and-america-on-911-20190911

post_text:
The PWHS Simon's Heart Club is trying to get the word out about a free heart screening for students ages 12-19. The screening will be held at Germantown Academy on Sept. 21, and donations are accepted. Sudden cardiac arrest is the #1 cause of death of student athletes. It takes the lives of thousands of students every year.

Click on the link for information and to register: https://simonsheart.org/blog/event/germantown-academy-screening/?event_date=2019-09-21

post_text:
Congratulations to Plymouth Whitemarsh High School Anatomy Teacher Sandy Comfort for being named one of Thomas Jefferson University's four Centennial Educator Award winners. PWHS Class of 2019 and Jefferson Pre-med Student Brooklynn Haasis nominated Comfort in an essay that would ultimately lead to the award.

"She taught me to stay positive, strong, and to keep chasing my dreams," said Ms. Haasis. "Mrs. Comfort has touched the hearts of many. Not only did I learn about the human body, but I also learned a lot about life and myself in her class."

#PWProud
#TeamColonial

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-teacher-sandy-comfort-named-centennial-educator-award-winner-20190910

Over the summer, Colonial Elementary's cafeteria was expanded to hold an additional 60-70 students.⁠
⁠
"Day one in the new cafeteria was awesome," explained Principal Rose Rock. "Students had a lot more room and the new sound panels look great and help with the noise. The new bottle filler and water fountain were quite popular."⁠
⁠
#WeAreColonial

Over the summer, Plymouth Whitemarsh High School Teacher Jim Muscarella spent a week in training at the University of Maryland. Mr. Muscarella is one of eight teachers in the country to pilot a new engineering course designed for #E4USA (Engineering For Us All), a program working to establish national standardized high school courses in engineering.
#PWProud
#WeAreColonial
Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-partners-with-virginia-tech-to-pilot-new-engineering-class-20190904

Plymouth Whitemarsh High School hosted approximately 350 incoming freshmen and transfer students for orientation program on Thursday. Newcomers had a chance to walk their schedules, meet with teachers and explore opportunities at an activities fair.

“It was helpful to find my way around the building,” said freshman Luke Caucci. “The upperclassmen were really helpful.”

#PWProud
#WeAreColonial
#schoolstartsonTuesday

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/incoming-students-get-a-taste-of-pwhs-20190829

Colonial School District is in the process of updating the phone system — a process that will take several weeks. During that time, if you are looking for a teacher or staff member at a particular school, please call the school directly and then follow the prompts to find their extension.

Conshohocken Elementary: 610-828-0362
Plymouth Elementary: 610-825-8190
Ridge Park Elementary: 610-825-1083
Whitemarsh Elementary: 610-828-9092
Colonial Elementary: 610-941-0426
Colonial Middle School: 610-275-5100
Plymouth Whitemarsh High School: 610-825-1500

The automated system for finding contacts from the main District number will work properly once the project is complete.

Members of the PW Service Club recently spent nine days of their summer vacation in a return visit to a rural K-6 school outside of Tecpán, Guatemala.

"I've grown as a person, and I know I'll definitely miss the friendships I've made, but the biggest thing I've learned was the power of volunteering," said Arya Venkat, a PWHS Junior. "Whether it's through doing something local or international, helping others is the way to make the world a better place."
#PWProud
#CSDsummer
#MakingADifferenceinCSD
Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/making-a-difference-the-pw-service-club-20190724

post_text: Congratulations, PW, for being named MONTCO.Today's School of the Week!
shared_text:
MONTCO.Today
July 22, 2019 at 12:00 PM ·

MONTCO.Today would like to honor our #SchoolOfTheWeek to the Plymouth-Whitemarsh High School! 🌟

The Plymouth-Whitemarsh High School is a highly rated, public high school located in Plymouth Meeting and of the Colonial School District. With over 1,400 students from grades 9th to 12th and a student-teacher ratio of 13 to 1, at least 89% of those students are proficient in reading and 87% are in math. The Plymouth-Whitemarsh High School impressively ranks 36th (out of 651) for Best Public High School Teachers and 38th for Best Public High Schools in Pennsylvania, according to niche.com. The Plymouth high school offers its students a challenging curriculum; a range of sports, clubs, and extracurricular activities to join; a kind, caring faculty and staff; and the proper tools and resources for you child to develop a successful career path. Congratulations and keep up the hard work! 😁

post_text: Congratulations to all the Colonial kids who raced in the Conshohocken Soap Box Derby on July 4 and a shout out to 2019 World Rally Super Stock Champion Erin Donovan, daughter of Conshohocken Elementary teacher Christine Donovan, and Matt Tomczak, who is Mrs. Donovan's nephew!
shared_text:
Conshohocken Borough
July 22, 2019 at 11:17 AM ·

The Borough of Conshohocken and Borough Council would like to extend a heartfelt CONGRATULATIONS to the following young individuals for their accomplishments. Erin Donovan, Matt Tomczak and Grace Gryga. Residents of Conshohocken, these three individuals traveled to Akron, OH to compete in the 82nd First Energy All-American International Soap Box Derby after competing in our Annual 4th of July Soap Box Derby.

Erin Donovan took home the 2019 World Rally Super Stock Championship (this is Erin’s 2nd win in this category), Matt Tomczak placed 2nd in the Local Stock Championship and Grace Gryga placed 5th in the World Rally Stock Championship.

CONGRATULATIONS on your well-deserved success!

post_text:
At their public business meeting on July 18, the Colonial Board of School Directors unanimously approved the submission of a Term Sheet outlining the proposed conditions of the District's purchase of the Romano property located at 1065 Belvoir Road in Plymouth Township.

If and when a sale is finalized, the District will continue to use the property as a bus depot in a lease agreement with First Student, its current transportation provider.

Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/july-school-board-news-20190718

post_text:
On an early Sunday morning in June, students from the PWHS Ronald McDonald Club volunteered for a Chef Guest breakfast at the Chestnut Street Philadelphia Ronald McDonald House. They spent hours preparing, serving and visiting with the families that were staying there.⁠
⁠
"The Chef Guest Breakfast provides a great opportunity for students to get together and help out families that are going through an extremely difficult time," said PWHS student and club officer Lenny Brenner.
⁠
#PWProud⁠
#MakingADifferenceinCSD⁠
Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/making-a-difference-pwhs-ronald-mcdonald-club-20190715

What a exciting partnership and a great opportunity for our kids!

post_text:
Reminder: Because of where Labor Day falls in the calendar, the Colonial school board has voted on the school start dates for the next three years:

2019-2020: Tuesday, September 3, 2019 (after Labor Day)
2020-2021: Monday, August 31, 2020 (before Labor Day)
2021-2022: Monday, August 30, 2021 (before Labor Day)

The rest of the 2020-2021 and 2021-2022 calendars will be determined at a later date.

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~news-id/6680

post_text:
What an honor to be helping St. Christopher's Hospital for Children's young patients get around! Colonial Middle School Art Teacher Julie Horwitz (second from left) dropped off the last of the 180+ lily pads, involving 480+ students who took Technology Education and/or Art at Colonial Middle School in the past three years!
#WeAreColonial
#ColonialCommunity
#TeamColonial
Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/cms-delivers-final-lily-pads-to-st-christophers-hospital-for-children-20190715
shared_text:
St. Christopher's Hospital for Children
July 15, 2019 at 11:49 AM ·

St. Christopher’s would like to thank Colonial Middle School in Plymouth Meeting, PA for their hard work and dedication in creating Lilypads for our patients to use during their hospital stay! The Lilypads help to decorate the IV pole and help the patients to personalize their experience. This three year partnership is a great example of the community support that helps St. Christopher’s provide excellent quality care to our patients and families

After learning how to build and program robots and drones during the week, the girls designed their own at the Girls In Technology Summer Academy. Volunteers from Lockheed Martin helped judge the results.

Congratulations to: Most Organized — Olivia Teeters and the team of Bridget Fullerton and Eliana Galleo, Most High In Demand Topic — Naomi Hoffman and the team of Manya Keswani and Gabi Durante, and Most Interesting Idea — the team of Julie Werner and Jade Zhang-Wong and the team of Alyssa VanBuren and Abby Falicki.

#CSDsummer
#STEAMinCSD
Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/colonials-girls-in-technology-summer-academy-teamed-with-lockheed-martin-20190709

post_text:
Thirty girls from fifth to eighth grade had the opportunity to program robots, fly drones and learn how to code tuition-free as part of the 2019 Girls In Technology Summer Academy, thanks to a grant from Lockheed Martin.

"I think it's cool how we're using robots and computers together," said Eliza Meersman, who'll be going into fifth grade at Colonial Elementary School in the fall. "I've liked the virtual reality, and I like all the different kinds of things we do."
#CSDsummer
#STEAMinCSD
Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/colonials-girls-in-technology-summer-academy-teamed-with-lockheed-martin-20190709

post_text: Do you have a middle schooler who's curious about what it would be like to be a first responder? Register your child for CMTHS - Central Montco Technical High School's Public Safety Day on July 18!
shared_text:
CMTHS - Central Montco Technical High School
July 8, 2019 at 11:29 AM ·

Ever wonder what it’s like to be a Fireman, Police Officer, or Emergency Medical Technician? Well now is your chance! On Thursday, July 18 during our Summer Grab A Day activity camp will be having a First Responders day to experience all of the exciting careers! There are still a few spots remaining so go to www.cmths.org and sign up now!

Watch for the Marching Colonials and Marching Colonials alumni in the Whitemarsh Fourth of July parade! Here are some pics from Tuesday's rehearsal!
#PWProud
#gettingthebandbacktogether

post_text:
Colonial recently hosted training that will help regular classroom teachers support the District’s 120+ English Language Learners (ELLs) — students who are learning English as a second language.

“The number of ELLs is growing, and we’re seeing the variety of languages grow, as well," said Dr. Katy Giovanisci, Curriculum Supervisor. "So the more familiarly we can build, the more prepared we’ll be.”
#TeamColonial
#CSDsummer
Read more:
https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/teachers-prepare-for-next-years-english-language-learners-20190703

post_text:
Seventy-five girls from grade four through grade eight recently worked on their volleyball skills with help from members of the PWHS Girls Volleyball team.

"It's fun, because I get to be with my friends and play volleyball," said camper Ava Sadowski.

Attendance for the PWHS Volleyball Camp has nearly doubled in five years.
#PWproud
#CSDsummer
Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~post/pwhs-volleyball-camp-nearly-doubles-in-size-over-five-years-20190701

post_text:
Already planning for next summer? Because of where Labor Day falls in the calendar, the Colonial school board has voted on the school start dates for the next three years:

2019-2020: Tuesday, September 3, 2019 (after Labor Day)
2020-2021: Monday, August 31, 2020 (before Labor Day)
2021-2022: Monday, August 30, 2021 (before Labor Day)

The rest of the 2020-2021 and 2021-2022 calendars will be determined at a later date.

Read more: https://www.colonialsd.org/news/item/~news-id/6680

Congratulations to Colonial's new Master Teachers: Rich Madel (Plymouth Whitemarsh High School), Tom Ortlieb (Plymouth Whitemarsh High School), Susan Burns (Colonial Elementary), Erin Powers (Plymouth Whitemarsh High School), Amy Campbell (Conshohocken Elementary), Brooke Carpenter (Colonial Middle School), Josh Rothstein (Colonial Middle School) and Jennifer Ramsden (Plymouth Elementary, not pictured).
